docs.lead_paragraph: Budd Goldman, an inventor in Mineola, N.Y., has earned his living for two decades making tchotchkies. ''Toilet paper holders that look like the back of cars, masks over shower heads that looked like celebrities, a little black box that you pushed it and it cursed,'' Mr. Goldman said, describing a few of his greatest hits. But now comes, at the end of the 20th century, what Mr. Goldman considers his crowning achievement: the Millennium Clock. ''I've been practicing to get to this one,'' he said.

headline.main: Compressed Data; Time to Set The Millennium Clock

docs.abstract: Budd Goldman, inventor in Mineola, NY, develops the Millennium Clock, desktop clock that counts down remaining hours, minutes and seconds until the arrival of Jan 1, 2000; has already sold a million millennium clocks, mostly to department stores and corporate clients; price is $24.95 each; clock photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Officials at both Winthrop and Catholic Health Services offered very cavalier answers to your reporter's queries about reproductive services in the two community hospitals that Winthrop and C.H.S. are taking over. Since Massapequa General and Mid-Island will have to operate under Catholic religious principles, there are many services they won't provide. Winthrop's John Broder said patients will be provided ''information'' about hospitals and doctors that offer the curtailed services. But with our limited choice of physicians because of managed care, patients won't always be able to find a doctor affiliated with a hospital still offering the services. And what if the patient is brought in with an emergency like a tubal pregnancy? Should her life be endangered while she is moved to a hospital that does therapeutic abortions? Women need services -- for contraception, infertility, sterilization and more -- not information about services. FLORENCE KAPLAN Plainview

headline.main: Saving Hospitals, But at What Cost?

docs.abstract: Florence Kaplan letter notes that Catholic hospital officials offered very cavalier answers to questions about reproductive services in to Long Island hospitals that are being taken over by Catholic management

docs.lead_paragraph: The proposed sponsorship of Massapequa General and Mid-Island Hospital by Catholic Health Services and Winthrop South Nassau University Health System (''Saving Hospitals, but Not All Their Parts,'' Aug. 9) is not as simple as the proponents of the plan allow. Family planning and reproductive services would not be the only victims of this proposed association. If these community hospitals are forced to abide by Catholic directives, the loss of services will be far-ranging. End-of-life services, such as living wills and powers-of-attorney for health care, may not be honored at a hospital that follows Catholic directives. H.I.V.-positive patients will not receive safe-sex counseling and instruction on condom use. Even basic emergency service such as therapeutic abortion for a tubal pregnancy will be denied.

headline.main: Saving Hospitals, But at What Cost?

docs.lead_paragraph: Shakeelah Gilyard stood on a chair in the community room of the North End Branch of the Newark Public Library, laughing nervously and leaning backward ever so tentatively. In an exercise to shore up trust among the group, several of Shakeelah's peers from Our Lady of Good Counsel High School knelt on the carpeted floor behind her, their hands and arms clasped, waiting to catch her in their human safety net. But Shakeelah had been dropped trying the same thing with another group a few years ago, bruising her head and shattering her trust, and finally, she stepped down off the chair. ''I'm a very independent person, and I just can't see myself depending on anybody,'' she said, her self-awareness, if not her confidence in others, expanded by the exercise.

headline.main: A Bit Older, a Bit Wiser, Seniors Will Counsel Sophomores

docs.abstract: Program at Newark, NJ, Catholic high school trains seniors to act as peer counselors for groups of sophmores; such counseling is commonly offered in parochial and public schools; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The maker of the Norplant contraceptive, which faces thousands of lawsuits claiming that it failed to warn of the device's potential side effects, has won the first suit that reached a jury verdict. A jury in Brownsville, Tex., took less than three hours on Thursday to rule in favor of the manufacturer, Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories, a subsidiary of the American Home Products Corporation.

headline.main: Contraceptive Maker Wins Woman's Suit Over Side Effects

docs.abstract: Jury in Brownsville, Tex, finds for Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories, maker of Norplant contraceptive, in lawsuit brought by Maria Olivia Valles, who contended that Norplant caused her severe menstrual bleeding, headaches, anemia and mood swings (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In an important advance for women's health, the Food and Drug Administration has approved the marketing and sale of emergency contraceptive pills that women can take within three days after sex to prevent pregnancy. For more than two decades, researchers have known that regular contraceptive pills that are taken daily to prevent pregnancy are also safe and effective if taken in larger doses as ''morning-after'' pills. Although this practice has been approved in many European countries, most American doctors offer their patients no guidance on it, so most women here know nothing about emergency contraception.
docs.abstract: Editorial welcomes Food and Drug Administration approval of marketing and sale of emergency contraceptive pills that women can take within three days after sex to prevent pregnancy; says hundreds of thousands of women may now be able to avoid unplanned pregnancies and subsequent abortions (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The rate at which American women die from complications related to pregnancy and childbirth has not budged in 15 years. From 1982 to 1996, maternal deaths occurred at an annual rate of 7 or 8 per 100,000 live births, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported today. The centers found that maternal deaths of black women ranged from 18 to 22 per 100,000 births, compared with 5 to 6 per 100,000 births for white women.

headline.main: National News Briefs; U.S. Pregnancy Deaths Hold at 15-Year Plateau

docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports that rate at which American women die from complications related to pregnancy and childbirth has not budged in 15 years; there have been 7 or 8 maternal deaths per 100,000 live births from 1982 to 1996; maternal deaths of black women range from 18 to 22 per 100,000 births, compared with 5 to 6 per 100,000 births for white women (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration today approved the first sales and marketing of a kit of emergency contraceptive pills that women can take the morning after unprotected sex to prevent pregnancy. The kits, known as Preven, will be available by prescription by the end of September, said Roderick Mackenzie, chairman and founder of Gynetics, the kit's manufacturer, in Somerville, N.J..
docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration approves first sales and marketing of kit of emergency contraceptive pills that women can take morning after unprotected sex to prevent pregnancy; kits, known as Preven, are manufactured by Gynetics Inc (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Yesterday was a boon for investors in three makers of cancer drugs. After an advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration recommended the approval of taxmoxifen as a means to reduce the risk of breast cancer, the shares of Zeneca Group P.L.C., which makes the drug, and Barr Laboratories, which sells its generic form, both rose sharply.

headline.main: For 3 Drug Makers, F.D.A. Makes Their Day

docs.abstract: Advisory committee to Food and Drug Administration recommends approval of taxmoxifen as means to reduce risk of breast cancer, and Genentech Inc receives FDA advisory committee approval for Herceptin, drug to treat metastatic breast cancer; shares of Zeneca Group PLC, which makes taxmoxifen, and Barr Laboratories, which sells its generic form, rise sharply, as do shares of Genentech Inc, which makes Herceptin (M)
